Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2010 02:59PM khartoregon wrote: As a relative newbie and complete novice at this, I add my thanks.  This board gives me hope and answers when "the real world" gives me prayers and funny looks.  Even the blood-drawer at the cancer center cringed when I responded to his question about my astrological sign.  Dude.  What?  Am I supposed to lie and say I'm a Leo??  At least in here it's okay to talk about the cancer.  Thank you, ladies.
Posts.Title: To the wonderful ladies on this board... RobinWendy vickib

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2010 11:12AM khartoregon wrote: Wow, granny, you're getting stressed out about the stress question.  So I'll say yes, stress causes breast cancer in the hopes that you will be calm and let your calmness regress the disease. By they way, cancer doesn't run in my family, and although I had a lot going on the past 4 years (full time work and college) my blood pressure is consistently low and I don't think I've got all that much stress, so I don't think stress gave me cancer. Maybe it was all those years cooking bachelorette dinners in the microwave and breathing in Los Angeles smog.  Go figure.
Posts.Title: Stress and Breast Cancer lukejessesmom texasrose361

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2010 04:11PM khartoregon wrote: Indeed Sydney!  I actually told the blood guy "I'm a Cancer, heh, pun intended" and he still had that awful foot-in-the-mouth look.  He works in a freakin' cancer center and this is the first time he's had a July birthday girl in the blood-draw chair?  Honestly....
Posts.Title: To the wonderful ladies on this board... RobinWendy vickib

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 04:59AM khartoregon wrote: Unfortunately I don't know anything about what those notes mean, but they should be interpreting them for you at the hospital.  What kind of doctors throw that kind of language out and leave it hanging?  Ayyyyyyyy that's just wrong. Ask for a copy of every scan report and take them to your primary care physician or a nurse or anyone who can tell you what that means, but most of all you have a right to know it in plain language from the doctor on the case.
Posts.Title: Help us help my MIL Faswilliams Faswilliams

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 10:29PM khartoregon wrote: Hey Frankie, I was in a similar ... okay not really too similar, but kind of similar situation a few months ago.  My boss had offered me a promotion at a time when my second treatment was failing.  I talked it over with the ladies in here and they convinced me to take it and I'm glad I did.   Now that my third treatment is taking a dive and there's a chance of things getting really iffy, I talked to the boss again and he still wants me to stay with the job for as long as possible.  He's very supportive and they even changed the insurance to a plan with a better drug program to cover chemo (I know! very nice people).  I guess I'm the only one in the office who really uses the insurance on a regular basis.  Go figure. Anyway, it depends on your boss and it sounds like your boss wants you there. So that's in your favor! The only thing I'm finding is that some days I don't want to be here, but those are the days when I don't want to be anywhere, so it's not the job so much as my energy level.  But if I could do this 3 days a week ... man, that would be brilliant.  So I think you've got a pretty good set-up there and I say you go for it. (I don't know nothing about birthin' babies, so I'm not going to weigh-in on that one.)
Posts.Title: Reaching for fallen stars? Seeking Candid Feedback! Frankie_ barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2010 01:56AM khartoregon wrote: Ahhhh I love good news.
Posts.Title: Good news Diana63 clemson93

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2010 08:55AM khartoregon wrote: I just had a PET last Wednesday.  I've had severe pain in my right side since Thursday and called the onc who said nothing shows up on the PET.  (Other stuff did, in spades ... great ...)  So I went to the hospital last night figuring maybe it was gall stones or something non-cancer, but it's not my gall bladder or my liver.  They did x-rays and saw nothing, so the doctor looked again at the PET and said there *might* be a lesion on the rib.  Then he shot me full of pain meds and sent me home. So maybe it's a lesion, but if it's too small to show up on the PET why does it hurt so much?  Not only that, but I feel like they think I'm a faker because they can't find anything in the scans.  Since my tumor markers don't indicate anything useful scans are all I have.  Sucks when they don't tell you what you want to know.
Posts.Title: Do PET scans work for you? JOxnop mthomp2020

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2010 09:48AM khartoregon wrote: Well, my onc read the report first, but he was reading the radiologist's interpretation and it showed nothing there.  Last night it was an ER doctor who went over it with a radiologist on hospital staff and apparently they saw the slight lesion in the actual scan.
Posts.Title: Do PET scans work for you? JOxnop mthomp2020

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2010 08:47AM khartoregon wrote: I've had terrible itchyness back there every time.  It's usually fine the day of the dose and then gets worse throughout the week.  I'm allergic to benedryl -- ha! I know, it cracks me up every time I say that.  It gives me really, really bad anxiety, so I stay clear of benedryl if I can.  But I didn't have hives, as far as I know, only a desperate need to scratch.  Okay, so long story, sorry --- basically I just ride it out and hope it goes away before the next shot.  Since I was getting hit every 2 weeks that used to be a problem, but now I'm on a monthly schedule for the shots and it seems to be okay.
Posts.Title: faslodex and hives 33skidoo justjudie

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2010 02:36PM khartoregon wrote: Well, okay, you can beat me up, it's fair, but I felt a lump this time last year and didn't get it checked until the following February.  I really thought it would go away --- I've been told I have "dense breasts" (albeit somewhat medium sized) subject to cysts and even in February my gyno said it was probably a cyst, but set up the mammogram anyway.  I have no history of breast cancer in my family.  I was active with cycling and regular walks.  I just didn't think it would come back cancer and then it did. So, yeah, I waited and watched on my own physical nickel and look what happened.  It was Stage IV at the dx.  Who knows if it was Stage IV in November.  Maybe.  Maybe not.  I'll never know.
Posts.Title: Wait and Watch...Not AliceJean Spoonchek

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2010 09:32AM khartoregon wrote: I hate losing people I love I hate losing people I don't know and yet have so much in common with I hate not knowing what to do when these things happen because I've cried so much it's beginning to feel like a reflex instead of real emotion I hate the look on my oncologist's face when he gives me the results of my scans I hate having to tell my mom that the scan results were not good and hope is not a guarantee I hate going to the hospital, seeing doctors, wearing an emergency contact bracelet like some 5 year-old who might get lost on the way to the playground I hate my cane I hate the pain, the lack of sleep, the inability to get comfortable I hate cancer

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 08:22AM khartoregon wrote: Halloween is more important to me than Christmas.  I know = bad Catholic and big nerd - last year I made my own Star Trek uniform out of stuff from Goodwill.  But I love being someone else every year.  I always go big, even before the idea of the "last Halloween" came into my world.  The theme for the party this year is pop culture, so who better than Lady GaGa?  She's such a clown that I figured I could wear anything outrageous with a kooky blond wig.  But, boy, try finding fishnet stockings with control top...
Posts.Title: Halloween Fitztwins JeninMichigan

Posts.Content: khartoregon wrote: I don't often post in here because I'm still very new to cancer and don't have a lot of experience to share, but I lurk all the time and read a lot, and I decided if there was a place to rant it would be here.  I keep my full-time job because I really need the insurance, but we've got one of those plans that requires you to use "In Network" doctors.  They pay 80% of the bill if you stick with the Network.  If you use "Out of Network" doctors they only cover 40%, so I've been very careful to check everyone out before committing to a doctor. But, it turns out the anesthesia team at the "In Network" hospital is part of an "Out of Network" group.  I didn't get a choice on my anesthesia physician when I had my oopherectomy and now I'm rooked with a $1300 bill.  To make it worse, there isn't an "In Network" anesthesia team in my city, so I'm going to get hit again when I have the lumpectomy/mastectomy (whatever it turns out to be) in August.  That is unless I go in high or with a slug of whiskey or whatever other absurd and useless alternative I have. Just when I got over the cancer itself being unfair, THIS crap happens. Thanks for the space. "I am not young enough to know everything." —Oscar Wilde Dx 3/8/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A Moment of Rant khartoregon khartoregon

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2010 08:22PM khartoregon wrote: Nicki, that is messed up and wrong.  This makes me so angry!  I mean, when I got that notice from my insurance company I had spent the day reading up on the pros and cons of reconstruction --- so, I've got to decide if I want to replace my breasts AND deal with a stupid paperwork glitch???  How f---ked up is that?  What they're doing to you is completely immoral and it's got to be stopped.  There's got to be something your doctor can do.  Doctors keep insurance companies in business, maybe they can throw some weight on this.

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2010 01:02PM khartoregon wrote: This makes me so angry and frustrated and bitter and feeling so useless.  Is "the Lord" so selfish that he's got to remove mothers from their children during a time of year when we're all supposed to be celebrating His life?!?  Really?  Is that how religion works?  How much closer to atheism am I right now?  This just makes me want to rant bad, terrible things.  This gives me no hope.  Tonya, I'm sorry you're gone and all I can think of are angry expletives, which are of no use to your children.  I'd pray for them, but praying for you didn't do jack.  I was an idiot to think it did.

Posts.Title: Tell me about Faslodex blondiex46 blondiex46

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2010 11:05AM khartoregon wrote: I actually went the other way, from percocet to vicodin because I didn't like being so cloudy-headed at work.  I don't sleep well, but it's more from anxiety (hello ativan!) than pain.  The pain comes and goes and I don't take anything unless it's constant or if it is more irritating than the anxiety.  Sometimes my neck will be stiff and creaky and cause headaches, but mostly it hurts to stand up and then I walk it out a little or sometimes my back feels knobby (is that weird?) and I pop the pill. So far I like the vicodin.  It's not strong, but it dulls the knobby bits enough to function and it's a good friend and companion to the ativan.  But, honestly, I still keep a bottle of the percocet handy in case things get dicey.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 11:32AM khartoregon wrote: I took a boat load of steroids at the beginning of the year and felt pretty good --- had a nice rush for New Year's Eve --- but the crash left me tired.  Or maybe that was the Xeloda.  It's hard to say.  My doctor suggested combining Miralax and Senacot for constipation.  It worked last week, but is a little slow moving this time around.  Anyway, the steroids jacked my platelet count to 314 and took away some odd pain I was having in my ribs, so it does something good in there.  I'm on it again for the next two days to get out of the platelet basement and I hope it works again. Karen

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2010 12:33PM khartoregon wrote: This year my little brother sent me a book called Farts: A Spotter's Guide.  It comes with sound effects: little buttons that are numbered to match a description of a fart in the book like "The Poof" or "The Flight of the Bumble Bee". I was so mad at him at first.  But we've since used it while leaving phone messages, watching television (it's great for news casts) and we leave it out on the table so friends can push the buttons as they walk by. Turns out my 7 year-old niece is the one who picked it out.  She's a keeper.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 09:20AM khartoregon wrote: So far nothing I've done has been successful, but if Xeloda works I'm going to push hard to keep it going, especially since it looks like this Rituximab is helping with my pesky platelet problems.  I'm even going to stick with work and put aside all the disability/retirement talk unless things get really bad.  I like having insurance and my boss just initiated a new policy that cancer people get 2 extra days off a month to take as-needed during treatment.  I'm the only one with cancer in the office, so this made me cry.  Isn't that the nicest thing you've ever heard?  How can I quit now? Besides the oxycontin doesn't dope me up as much as I thought it would and I function better than the majority of people in my department -- it's fun to remind them that I'm fixing their screw-ups while on drugs. Karen

Posts.Content: khartoregon wrote: Hello Ladies, Scans came back with progression so I'm moving from Tamoxifen to Faslodex.  The first shot is on 10/18.  The good news is I can stop taking the Tamoxifen starting tomorrow, since it wasn't working anyway, which means so long constant hot flashes just in time for Vegas.  Bad news is I'm on my last hormone option and if this doesn't work I am well and truly done.  Anyone have good Faslodex stories?  If it means sleeping through the night I'm already happy for the change. Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 12:41PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:50AM by khartoregon What really bothers me about this month is the false hope it's giving my family.  My parents, God love 'em, did the Komen walk last weekend and now my mom is filled with stories of cures and remission and hope, and it's really hard to keep reminding her that I'm not one of those cures and remissions people.  They're not going to take this tumor out and then it's gone, no matter what they say on The View.  I've got a PET and an MRI on Friday and her response to that was "Don't do it.  Why do they have to keep doing so many scans?" because I know she doesn't want to hear that things are worse or even that things are the same, because that means cancer is still there and didn't they just say at the pink booth during the walk that cures are being found every day?  Every day, Karen.  You can beat this thing. People also don't understand that just because you can't "beat" it doesn't mean you can't keep living your life.  I'm still - still - getting advice not to take my new position here at the office because of the cancer, and I feel fine.  Even if I can only do this job for 6 months, that's 6 months of working and good insurance and being a regular person like anyone else out there.  Give us that publicity, you Sheryl Crow people!  I'm here.  I have cancer.  I'm still here. We fight this every day and the battle isn't to beat it, but to live with it and that is the struggle that they need to acknowledge.  We live with it knowing it's not going away, but we still get up and contribute to the world every day that we can.  The sooner medical science can make those days last longer the better.  They need to get on it. Oh and I am wearing pink today, but it's only because it matches the blue-green in my skirt.
Posts.Title: Why do I feel we are being overlooked cmhartley blondiex46

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2010 03:02PM khartoregon wrote: Our local news station posted an online story today about a woman who had a mastectomy and how much she "loves her new breasts" with a line at the end about how they want to hear from other women about how breast cancer and mastectomies have "affected your life."  So I commented that, hey, instead of covering the same old ground of mastectomy-to-cure maybe they could talk a little about Stage IV survivors.  Maybe something will come of it.  Probably not.  "Cancer free" always adds that dash of hope to a human interest story ... wow, I feel so jaded from journalism school...

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2010 03:04AM khartoregon wrote: When I was dx'd last March I had a nurse tell me this:  "You're going to want to fight it, but when people offer help it's not weakness to accept it.  They want to do it.  Let them help you."  I'm also fiercely independent, always have been, so this is very difficult for me.  I hate not living my own life my way.  But that nurse was right.  If I let people do things when I don't have energy it frees me up to take care of my health.  Then, when I get back on my feet and steady, I can return to doing the other stuff.
Posts.Title: How to Stay Independent jleigh steelrose

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2010 12:11AM khartoregon wrote: This is why I don't like to go to Race of the Cure anymore.  We went to Relay for Life in August and they did a Survivor's Lap and my friends were standing up and applauding and I just couldn't get out of my head: "Sweet Jesus, look how many people have cancer.  That can't be right."  I didn't do the lap with the others.  I couldn't cheer cancer "cured" or not.  We left right afterward.  Didn't stay for the candle lighting or anything.  This is affecting far too many people for my liking.

He's not half the man his father is.  There's nothing in this world can stop Kirk.  That guy is my hero.

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2010 05:10PM khartoregon wrote: Frapp, we share a cosmic link.  I've had the same trouble today (constant back ache + cubicle).  I walked at lunch and rode my bike to work, but nothing's "popping" the muscle pain out, so now it's got me worried that it could be something else, which means I feel stupid, freak out, feel stupid, but what if?, feel stupid ... etc ... all in the familiar chain of panic. A couple of times I've gone to the ladies' room just to get away and once I called my mom, but she wasn't home.  And I don't even have radiation to blame for it. Oh and I still have to ride the bike home at 5 and the prospect makes me want to cry (but crying at work is for sissies .... which I guess maybe that's what I am).

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2010 06:57AM khartoregon wrote: Geez, Lynn, you know, just an hour ago I sat in the car cursing and crying because my brother forgot my birthday.  What the f..k?  Like I care what that selfish a-hole does or doesn't do.  But it felt like part of a bigger, crappier mess of crappy mess.  So I finally decided to ask my doctor for those medications he keeps suggesting.  Anti-depressants in my family is akin to committing seppuku, without the honor --- you've given up, you weakling!  Why can't you get over it!  But, you know, my family hasn't been through this and, yeah, sitting in this cubicle every day listening to everyone else go on vacation because they haven't used all their time-off on scans and infusions or trying to decide whether or not I want to replace my breasts -- this is definitely not something you just "get over" and little things turn big very quickly. But thank God for this forum.  Without it, I would be a bitter angry mess.  I mean, I am bitter and angry, but not a mess ... yet.  We'll see what happens with the chemical love. I'm not a hugger, but I would hug all of you if I could.
Posts.Title: First Chemo on Friday Lynn1 pee

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2011 12:11PM khartoregon wrote: Wow, so no one else has the joint pain?  I wonder if it's just that new shoulder met acting up on me although it mostly feels like muscle pain.  I also had this weird muscle spasm in my calf yesterday.  I tend to blame anything unexplained on the chemical input, but maybe it's the combination of coming down from weekend steroids and adding the Xeloda Tuesday.  All things considered, Xeloda isn't too bad.  I hope it evens out at some point so I don't fall asleep at my desk anymore. heh. Karen
Posts.Title: xeloda Sunshine32 Windtalker

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 12:29PM khartoregon wrote: I haven't done Gemzar, only Xeloda, but I've had platelet issues for years, even before the cancer. Currently I'm on a 4 week regimen of Rituximab, which is something they usually give to lymphoma patients, but it's kind of hit or miss.  It seems to be missing with me.  Transfusions are temporary, as are steroids, and steroids are no good for bones either, but for the instant pop they seem to work okay.  My spleen is also the issue, always has been, so next up for me is nPlate, but I'm not starting it yet.  The main problem with nPlate is once you stop you could drop even further down than where you were when you started or so says the 4 pages of release forms. It's a mess.  If your bone marrow biopsy comes back okay --- if the issue is the spleen and not the marrow --- that's when they start talking nPlate and Rituximab. Good luck!  Karen

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 06:14PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:52AM by khartoregon Okay, I'm going to blow a fuse --- insurance companies or Medicare won't pay for treatment?!?  How is that justified?  Gahhhhhhhhhhhhh I hate cancer.  As if we don't have enough to fear without getting an outrageous medical bill to treat something we don't f.....ng want in the first place!  THIS is why I hate pink month.  Where are the Komen funds to cover these costs? Sorry, I'm waiting on scan results (hey, and maybe a bill for the PET scan which was $7000 or so based on the last one and I could barely scrape together the $600 that was my portion) and it's made me all edgy.  I also had sugar at lunch.  Sorry.  But I'm not doing another flipping pink walk until I get some payback, that's all I'm saying.

Posts.Title: indignities apple pattih

Posts.Content: khartoregon wrote: This is really hard.  Nanalinda, Irina, Heather --- people I've recognized and people I don't even know are not making it and this helplessness is so very frustrating and it makes me angry. Today would have been my friend Kelly's 38th birthday.  She was dx'd in 2009, had a double mastectomy and her lymph nodes were sent to 3 hospitals who pronounced them cancer free.  Five months later it was in her liver.  She did chemo, changed her eating habits to organic food and macrobiotics, went to a Reiki healer, practiced meditation and she still died in May just as my companion cancer journey was starting.  I couldn't even go to her memorial service. She did everything right and it still didn't matter.  She would have been 38 today.  Her son turned 2 in June. This is why I don't have faith in prayer (she had a convent of Carmelite nuns praying for her survival) or medicine and lately I'm running really short on hope.  I hate pink month and its inherent expectations and accusations --- you don't exercise/eat well/pray enough.  We DO exercise, eat well and, yes, many people pray, and it doesn't matter. I'm sorry, I can't believe in good scans.  I can't believe in happiness.  I find it difficult to pray for success or peace, because it seems to be denied us until the end when chemicals can put us to sleep and take away our fear and pain. I miss you, Kelly.  I miss you, Nanalinda.  I miss you, Irina, and your stories about your cats.  I will one day miss a lot of people that I know and some that I don't know.  I will one day have to say good-bye to this board -- a board I came on to find companionship that will one day be lost to me. Cancer is a heartless bastard. "I am not young enough to know everything." —Oscar Wilde Dx 3/8/2010, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 08:29AM khartoregon wrote: My oncologist keeps threatening to do a bone marrow biopsy, but they're painful and maybe it's the way I cringe that puts him off it.  I've had platelet issues for a few years and now, as of Monday, I've got to keep an eye on the red count which may or may not dip down into anemia.  So it would not surprise me that there were mets in the marrow, but the only way to know for sure is the big needle and, in the end, I wonder if it would make a difference.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 11:37AM khartoregon wrote: Wow, you guys need to come out here to Oregon.  My oncologist has been very supportive through all of this.  He doesn't want to cause me any unncessary pain, but will still move me from treatments that aren't working and does frequent scans.  I see him every 2 weeks at least, but we go back a long way.  He was my blood doctor before he became my cancer doctor.  Of course the surgeon originally assigned to do my lumpectomy wrote me off at Stage IV and that was irritating, but since the surgery was cancelled I haven't had to see her again.
Posts.Title: stage IV "discrimination"? jenny66 lindaa

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2010 08:33AM khartoregon wrote: I have not had surgery although the original idea was to shrink the tumor and do a lumpectomy.  That was cancelled after the PET scan showed the metastesis.  My oncologist says there's arguments for and against it, but doesn't think surgery is a good idea for me because I have a low platelet count.  I suppose if I had normal blood like everyone else I'd probably want it out of there and, at the size it's at now (even though it did shrink 1.3 cm), that would be mastectomy.
Posts.Title: How many of you did not have surgery? Suebus Chris93

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 08:01PM khartoregon wrote: You know, I'm already going through my stuff to see what I can sell on eBay to make money to pay off my co-pays and deductables and I work full-time and have fairly decent insurance.  Flippin' hell, if I end up on Medicare or part time or losing insurance, it just doesn't seem fair that I've got to pick and choose treatment based on cost.  I've got limited options as it is now without that in the mix. More on topic:  I was on arimidex first and got switched off of it just as it went generic.  Bitter.  Isn't.  Pretty.  Anyway I didn't have any more SE's with arimidex than I'm having with tamoxifen, although maybe the hot flashes were a little more frequent with arimidex.  The pills are small, if I remember correctly.  That's a plus if you're like me and hate taking them.  I did have bone mets progression tho', but that might be the arimidex and it might be the steroids I was on for my platelets.  It's hard to say.

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2010 12:28PM khartoregon wrote: I knew you all would understand.  It's a very hard day today.  Very hard. This came about not only because I saw the update on Heather this morning, but also because last night I had to (yet again) tell my mother that the scans showed progression and it kills me when she replies with "Well, lesions don't necessarily mean cancer.  They don't know for sure." and that she believes what she's saying and I have to be the a-hole and tell her, "no, mom, they do know for sure and it is cancer" and hear her get quiet and let it sink in.  This is so painful and unfair and for what?  This doesn't run in my family.  It didn't in Kelly's family either.  We're just lucky.  My mom also told me -- in reference to you vickib and a posting last week about how some insurance and medicaire may not cover Faslodex, those jerks -- that the American Cancer Society has a fund to help pay for treatments if you can't afford them. Damned if I can find that on their website.

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2010 05:08PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:48AM by khartoregon Suzy, I come from a family where getting an MRI is like dabbling in witchcraft.  Last week, while I was visiting my parents, I was taking vicodin so I could sleep through the night and my father barked at me that "pills were for druggies!" Good thing I'm at a point where that actually made me laugh ("Oh, Pop, for heaven's sake..."). Anyway, I'm not a druggie, but if I don't calm my bone pain and my crazy thoughts for at least a few hours a night, I'm not going to be doing my overall health any favors.  I'm also afraid of getting hooked, but I think that the realization that it could turn into something I can't put down is what will keep me from dependency.  I only take it when I need it, and, yes, some weeks that's every day.  But sometimes I can actually skip a few days and I know my body enough to know when to stop and when to start.  If that changes, well, then I guess I'll be a druggie. But there's no reason in the world why you should be expected to live your life in pain.  Or I haven't found a reason yet anyway.  If someone comes up with one I guess I'll give it a go.  Until then, you have a right to live your life without crying. (Oh, yes, sorry, just to add -- I don't have LE.  Sorry, but, sure, I do understand pain.  You bet.)

My family lives too far away, so I've got to manage it here, but I guess there comes a point where it makes more sense to shift priorities away from other people or jobs and take care of yourself more.  It will be different for everyone.  I'm not sure, but I think that shift might happen for me soon. Karen

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 06:45PM khartoregon wrote: I'm with you English -- I tend to get sparky over stupid crap ... you know, like watching "Dallas" or really, really, really wanting to ride my bicycle, but it's raining (and some jerk stole my rain pants last year and I'm too bitter to buy another pair) or those irritating co-workers who baby talk in the next cubicle.  Makes me want screech like a harpy and throw things. I tend to cry over the same stuff I cried over before the cancer:  cheesy Bollywood movies, that commercial about taco night in the lovely Craftsman home (I'll never have that home; I'll never have those children -- why? why?). But maybe it's the steroids I have to take pushing the emotional fireworks into a kind-of double-negative cancellation.  I guess I'll see what happens the first time I take a shower after the steroid treatment ends.
Posts.Title: Just CRYING.. llanabeth donnabee

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2011 09:46AM khartoregon wrote: I had this the week of Christmas.  It felt like someone was kicking me.  I timed them at intervals of 35 - 40 seconds apart and when that interval shrunk I called the onc.  He said there was nothing showing there on the PET scan, so I thought it might be gall stones or maybe I broke or sprained something and went into Urgent Care.  Those guys just shot me full of diluadid and sent me home saying it might be a slight lesion, but they also couldn't really see anything on the PET. Slight lesion my left eye.  This thing was too strong to be slight anything! Anyway, fast forward a few days and onc throws me on steroids to up my counts for chemo and pain goes away.  So, I don't know what it was, but steroids knocked it out pretty quickly. For all the lack of anything at Urgent Care, they did do a pee test and confirmed for me that at least it wasn't my liver or gall bladder.  Not much comfort to know they couldn't figure out what it was, but at least I know I've still only got bone mets.  It might be worth a trip to your primary care doc or Urgent Care (at least you'll get dilaudid).
Posts.Title: rib pain or is it liver pain? Honeybear Marybetz
